qas.question: What is one proposed explanation for the instant appearance of flowering plants?
What is island genetics thought to be a default source of?
What did radical adaptations seem to have required?
How did an isolated setting like an island help flowering plants evolve?

answers.text: highly specialized relationship with some specific animal

qas.question: What are transitional forms descended from?
What is an explanation for the sudden appearance of fig wasps?

plausible_answers.text: the development of a high degree of specialization

qas.question: What does a relationship between bees and wasps result in?
What is carrying pollen thought to be a common source of?

plausible_answers.text: a highly specialized relationship with some specific animal

qas.question: How did flowering plants help transitional forms evolve?

context: <a0_0><b6_0>Island genetics<b6_0/><a0_0/> provides one proposed explanation for the sudden, fully developed appearance of flowering plants. Island genetics is believed to be a common source of <a1_0><b8_0>speciation<b8_0/><a1_0/> in general, especially when it comes to radical adaptations that seem to have required <a2_0>inferior transitional forms<a2_0/>. Flowering plants may have evolved in an isolated setting like an island or island chain, where the plants bearing them were able to develop <b9_0>a <a3_0>highly specialized relationship with some specific animal<b9_0/><a3_0/> (a wasp, for example). Such a relationship, with a hypothetical wasp carrying pollen from one plant to another much the way fig wasps do today, could result in <b7_0>the development of a high degree of specialization<b7_0/> in both the plant(s) and their partners. Note that the wasp example is not incidental; bees, which, it is postulated, evolved specifically due to mutualistic plant relationships, are descended from <a4_0><b5_0>wasps<b5_0/><a4_0/>.
